Intro R

Intro

How to learn R?

There are many options. - YouTube - Coursera - Possibly an LLM

CRAN = the Comprehensive R Archive Network Go here to download: R https://cran.r-project.org/

Base R = the functions and packages that come pre-installed (are native) to R

Rstudio = an interactive development environment (IDE)

Formats where code can be stored (and executed):

  • Code is just text, you could put it in a word document

  • an “R script” refers to a simple text file with the extension .R

  • Rdata: Multiple R objects

  • rds: Single R objects

  • Rmd and Qmd: Rmarkdown and Quarto markdown files

    • These are plain text files
    • For “literate programming”.
    • They are good for communicating! They combine the narrative + display the code + the the results of it’s execution in a unified, reproducible report format.
    • They can be compiled (“knitted”) into various output formats (e.g. PDF, html)

First steps with R

Vectors

a <- c(1, 2, 3)
g <- c("A", "B", "A")

dim(a)
NULL
as.matrix(a)
     [,1]
[1,]    1
[2,]    2
[3,]    3
dim(as.matrix(a))
[1] 3 1

Type consistency

Matrices

X <- matrix(c(1, 0,
              1, 1,
              1, 0), nrow = 3, byrow = TRUE)

X
     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    0
[2,]    1    1
[3,]    1    0
dim(X)
[1] 3 2

Recall:

\[ y = X\beta + \epsilon \]

Matrix multiplication

beta <- c(10, 2)

# Matrix multiplication
X %*% beta
     [,1]
[1,]   10
[2,]   12
[3,]   10
beta * beta
[1] 100   4
beta %*% beta
     [,1]
[1,]  104

Cross products and transpose

t(X) %*% X
     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    3    1
[2,]    1    1
t(X) %*% c(10, 12, 11)
     [,1]
[1,]   33
[2,]   12

\[ \hat{\beta} = (X^TX)^{-1}X^Ty \]

y <- c(10, 12, 11)
solve(t(X) %*% X) %*% t(X) %*% y
     [,1]
[1,] 10.5
[2,]  1.5

Factors

f <- factor(g)
levels(f)
[1] "A" "B"

important for modeling, factors matter for design matrices

data.frames

df <- data.frame(y = c(10, 12, 11),
                 geno = factor(c("G1", "G2", "G1")),
                 block = factor(c(1, 1, 2)))
str(df)
'data.frame':   3 obs. of  3 variables:
 $ y    : num  10 12 11
 $ geno : Factor w/ 2 levels "G1","G2": 1 2 1
 $ block: Factor w/ 2 levels "1","2": 1 1 2
  • Columns = variables
  • Rows = observations
  • mixed variable types
  • technically, a special case of a list

Lists

m <- lm(y ~ geno + block, data = df)
str(m)
List of 13
 $ coefficients : Named num [1:3] 10 2 1
  ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:3] "(Intercept)" "genoG2" "block2"
 $ residuals    : Named num [1:3] 0 0 0
  ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:3] "1" "2" "3"
 $ effects      : Named num [1:3] -19.053 -1.225 0.707
  ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:3] "(Intercept)" "genoG2" "block2"
 $ rank         : int 3
 $ fitted.values: Named num [1:3] 10 12 11
  ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:3] "1" "2" "3"

  .. .. ..- attr(*, "response")= int 1

  .. .. ..- attr(*, "predvars")= language list(y, geno, block)
  .. .. ..- attr(*, "dataClasses")= Named chr [1:3] "numeric" "factor" "factor"
  .. .. .. ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:3] "y" "geno" "block"
 - attr(*, "class")= chr "lm"

Matrix operations

References

  • Ferrao - MAS - Intro to Linear Models
  • Ferrao - QG - WK2a - Why models?
  • Isik et al. 2017 - Ch. 2 - A Review of Linear Mixed Models

\[ y_{ij} = \mu + g_j + b_i + e_{ij} \]

\[ y = \mu + X_1g + X_2b + \epsilon \]
